docs.lead_paragraph: Faced with a to-do list that is long and getting longer, President Bush got off to a fast start today, acting to delay or block some of the Clinton administration's final initiatives. Less than two hours after taking the oath of office, Mr. Bush had his chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., take steps to keep his predecessor's last flurry of rules and regulatory decisions from taking effect.

headline.main: To Do: 1. Undo Most Recent Actions of My Predecessor

docs.abstract: Pres George W Bush moves quickly to delay or block some of Clinton administration's final initiatives; Bush's chief of staff, Andrew H Card Jr, says new president's appointees must have opportunity to review any new or pending regulations; Bush and his aides are eager to get to work; brief listing of issues they inherit or will face in near future (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: How Bad It Is to Be 20 Years Old The pill was white and smelled like No-Doz. Although it had come to us in the mail inside a tennis ball, it was legal then, fresh from a lab in Texas. No rumors, no culture surrounding it. We took it on a whim, on blind faith -- because it was Saturday and there was nothing better to do. It was late afternoon, warm for November in New Hampshire. Starting that day in 1984, and until May 1986, I ate Ecstasy, once or sometimes twice a month. During that same time I realized that the plan I'd made for my life (I was 20 years old) was useless. I kind of woke up. I didn't start wearing flowers in my hair, but I got more excited to live, made a new plan that felt freer -- a plan that sent me in the right direction. And I still wonder what the drug had to do with that. Maybe nothing. (How can a drug do anything for you? Generally I hate drugs. I don't even take Advil.) It's impossible to say. But because it was inside my noodle, I can't separate out the Ecstasy.
docs.abstract: Matthew Klam article describes his experiences with Ecstasy, fastest-growing illegal substance in America; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: At last spring's White House Correspondents Association dinner, Bill Clinton showed a now famous video sending up his own status as a lame-duck president. The video showed the leader of the free world buying smoked hams on eBay, doing his laundry, clipping the Rose Garden hedges, watching television with his dog and running after Hillary's limousine with a brown-bag lunch. In the ensuing days, Mr. Clinton was hailed for his gifts as a ham actor, and criticized for trivializing the status of his office. Mr. Clinton's loss of gravitas, of course, did not start with the video; it did not even start with Monica Lewinsky and her stained dress. It was there from the beginning.

headline.main: With the Guy Next Door in the Oval Office, the Presidency Shrinks Further

docs.abstract: Michiko Kakutani essay on Clinton presidency sees Clinton not only as first baby-boom persident, but as first user-friendly president: president as guy next door, one who feels our pain because he struggles with his weight, his marriage and his golf game; says shrinking of presidency that accelerated under Clinton will no doubt continue, given circumstances under which George W Bush will enter White House; photos of Clinton during last days in office (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed state budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 is the seventh spending plan he has issued as governor. In his budget, he proposed overall spending of $83.6 billion, a figure that includes federal aid for programs like welfare and Medicaid. If enacted, the budget would represent a 5.3 percent increase in state spending. The portion to be raised by the state totals $57.4 billion, up 4.9 percent. Of that, the general fund, which includes most tax revenue, would rise 3.6 percent, to $41.3 billion, though the definition of the fund has changed over the years to artificially limit its growth.
